Name: Scene Manager DSE

Documentation.Description:
Basic Concepts

This DSE works together with the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker – Context Awareness Platform in order to perform the event configuration, receive alert notifications, and manage the subscriptions to those events. A prototype web application has been developed for accessing the functionalities of the DSE. The figure below provides a screenshot of this web application, with the tab corresponding to the Scene Manager DSE.

Basic Design Principles

An instance of the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker – Context Awareness Platform is used to create rules with their corresponding alerts. This instance is fed with data from each of the trial modules/subsystems, and each time it receives data, a check is done in order to notify which scenes created from the web interface have been fulfilled (i.e. the parameters which define the scene match the specified ranges).

A service has been implemented which sends data as service listener notifications both to the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker – Context Awareness Platform and to a database for storage, so that it can be accessed through web services.

A programmed task in Java is in charge of creating the scenes in the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker - Context Awareness Platform, because this module cannot read directly from the internal databases of the trial.

Additionally, another programmed task is in charge of maintaining all the subscriptions active, because their period of expiration is too limited for the application requirements (less than 1 day). This is the reason why this Java task is being executed continuously – otherwise the subscriptions would be lost due to the restrictions of the Context Awareness Platform. Thus, the programmed task ensures that all alerts are triggered and sent when the scene parameters are within the configured ranges.

DSE Interwork

Documentation.Preface:
Within this document you find a self-contained open specification of the aforementioned Domain Specific Enabler (DSE).

Please consult the appropriate pages on the FINESCE website in order to understand the complete context of the related FINESCE trials and this DSE.
Documentation.ReutilisedTech: The Scene Manager DSE relies on the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker - Context Awareness Platform.

Usage:
Installation guide

The Scene Manager DSE consists of the following modules:
  • Java process to send scenes as subscriptions to the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker
  • Database. For the trial implementation a SQL Server 2012 has been used
  • User interface

The process which sends the subscriptions consists of a .jar executable file. In order to run it, it is necessary to place the file within the Java installation folder, or modify the environment "classpath" where it is located.

To run the process, it is necessary to run the following statement through the command line:
java –jar {PATH_TO_FILE}/FinesceJavaTask.jar

The process will be running continuously, checking the database in order to find new subscriptions for sending to the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker, and sending renewal statements to keep alive the scenes previously created.

For this process to work correctly, there will be a check field in the database that will indicate which subscriptions are new and need to be sent to the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker.

When a new subscription is created, the concerned trial module is chosen. Thus, in case of an alert the service running in the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker knows which module has triggered it. Alerts information is stored in the database, from which the data can be provided through any API or GUI.

The DSE uses a database for interacting with GEs. Two tables are used for storing the created subscriptions (FINESCE_Subscriptions and FINESCE_SubscriptionsParams) and the other two for storing the notifications generated by the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker (FINESCE_ctxEls and FINESCE_ctsEls_Data)

FINESCE_Subscriptions Table

This table keeps information related to all the scenes created. It has a record for each created scene
Structure: 


CREATE TABLE [dbo].[FINESCE_Subscriptions](
    [idsubscriptions] [uniqueidentifier] NULL,
    [name] [nchar](50) NULL,
    [date] [varchar](50) NULL,
    [subid] [int] NULL,
    [date_timestamp] [int] NULL,
    [idtemp] [int] NULL,
    [fecharenovacion] [int] NULL,
    [module] [varchar](50) NULL,
    [entity_name] [varchar](50) NULL,
    [entity_id] [varchar](50) NULL
) ON [PRIMARY]

Attribute "subid" identifies each subscription which has been created in the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker, and it is empty at the beginning. Once a subscription is successfully created, the value of "subid" returned using XML is collected, and the field of the database is updated to identify that the subscription has been successfully created.

Every time the automatic subscriptions renewal process (FinesceJavaTask.jar) is executed, the value of "fecharenovacion" with the time instant when the subscription is renewed is updated.

FINESCE_SubscriptionsParams Table

This table keeps the information related to the different parameters which belong to each scene, linked to the scene through the “idtemp” field. 


CREATE TABLE [dbo].[FINESCE_SubscriptionsParams](
    [idsubscriptionsparams] [uniqueidentifier] NULL,
    [subid] [int] NULL,
    [param_name] [nchar](50) NULL,
    [param_condition] [nchar](10) NULL,
    [param_value] [nchar](10) NULL,
    [param_order] [int] NULL,
    [date_timestamp] [int] NULL,
    [idtemp] [int] NULL
) ON [PRIMARY]

The attribute "subid" identifies each subscription which has been created in the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker GE, and it is empty at the beginning. Once the subscription is successfully created, the value of "subid" returned using XML is collected, and the field of the database is updated to identify the created subscription.

The table contains a record for every parameter defined for each scene. The XML code generated will contain as many elements as records this table has for each scene.

FINESCE_ctxEls Table

This table contains the records of the notifications received by a customer when an alert has been triggered in a scene. The scene “subid” parameter that triggered this alert is saved too, so that it is possible to keep track of all the alerts generated by every scene. 


CREATE TABLE [dbo].[FINESCE_ctxEls](
    [regId] [uniqueidentifier] NOT NULL,
    [regTimeStamp] [datetime] NOT NULL,
    [subId] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [contextProviderId] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [contextProviderV] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [entityId] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [entityType] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [scope] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [timestamp] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [expires] [nvarchar](256) NOT NULL,
    [alreadyViewed] [int] NULL,
 CONSTRAINT [PK_FINESCE_ctxEls] PRIMARY KEY CLUSTERED 
(

FINESCE_ctxEls_Data Table

This table contains all the parameter values of the scene which generated an alert 


CREATE TABLE [dbo].[FINESCE_ctxEls_Data](
    [regId] [uniqueidentifier] NOT NULL,
    [parameter] [nvarchar](50) NOT NULL,
    [value] [nvarchar](50) NOT NULL,
    [regTimeStamp] [datetime] NOT NULL,
 CONSTRAINT [PK_FINESCE_ctxEls_Data] PRIMARY KEY CLUSTERED 
(
    [regId] ASC,
    [parameter] ASC,
    [value] ASC
)WITH (PAD_INDEX  = OFF, STATISTICS_NORECOMPUTE  = OFF, IGNORE_DUP_KEY = OFF, ALLOW_ROW_LOCKS  = ON, ALLOW_PAGE_LOCKS  = ON) ON [PRIMARY]
) ON [PRIMARY]

Data model

The data model corresponding to the weather forecasting services is depicted below as an example:

Load Data

Request: 

http://publish_subscribe_ip/CB/ContextBroker/contextUpdate

Content-Type: 
    application/xml
Request body:
    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
    <contextML xmlns="http://ContextML/1.7" 
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"  
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://ContextML/1.7 ../ContextML-1.7.xsd">
        <ctxEls>
            <ctxEl>
                <contextProvider id="MyClient" v="1.2.1"/>
                <entity id="123456789123" type="imei"/>
                <scope>cell</scope>
                <timestamp>2014-02-05T10:10:10+01:00</timestamp>
                <expires>2020-01-01T10:10:10+01:00</expires>
                <dataPart>
                    <par n="dirviento">4</par>
                    <par n="humrel">4</par>
                    <par n="modviento">4</par>
                    <par n="precip">4</par>
                    <par n="temp">4</par>               
                </dataPart>
            </ctxEl>
        </ctxEls>
    </contextML>

Response: 

Response code:
    200 OK
Content-Type:
    application/xml
Response body:
    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
    <contextML xmlns="http://ContextML/1.7" 
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://ContextML/1.7 http://contextml.tilab.com/ContextML-1.7.xsd">
        <ctxResp>
            <contextProvider id="CB" v="1.4.5"/>
            <timestamp>2015-02-03T12:38:40+02:00</timestamp>
            <entity id="123456789123" type="imei"/>
            <method>contextUpdate</method>
            <resp status="OK" code="200"/>
        </ctxResp>
    </contextML>

Notifications to the client 

Response code:
    200 OK
Content-Type:
    application/xml
Response body:
    ctxData=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
     <contextML>
      <ctxEls>
        <ctxEl subId="62">
          <contextProvider id="CB" v="1.4.5"/>
          <entity id="123456789123" type="imei"/>
          <scope>cell</scope>
          <timestamp>2015-02-03T12:38:40+02:00</timestamp>
          <expires>2020-11-20T16:37:55+01:00</expires>
          <dataPart>
            <par n="temp">4</par>
          </dataPart>
        </ctxEl>
      </ctxEls>
     </contextML>

Methods

Get Alerts: This method provides the last notifications which the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker has sent to the client. It accepts GET parameters:

  • method It shall be a String, representing the format of output data. There are two possible values:
    • json
    • xml
  • fecha_ini It shall be an Integer representing a date in UNIX_TIMESTAMP format.
  • fecha_fin It shall be an Integer representing a date in UNIX_TIMESTAMP format.
  • module Should be an String, representing the module from which the alerts are provided (meteo, wsn, …).
  • parameter It shall be a String, representing a parameter (temp, humrel, …). This parameter is optional.

Example

GET 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/{module_name}/{function_name}/?parameters

Example using JSON 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/wf/getalerts/?action=service_alerts&method=json&module=wf&parameter=temp&fecha_ini=1421931600&fecha_fin=1423054800

REQUEST

ACCEPT
    application/json

RESPONSE
Response code:
    200 OK
Content-Type:
    application/json
Response body:
    {"meteo": [
        { 
            "temp":"6.29" ,  
            "humrel":"0.60" ,  
            "precip":"0.20" ,  
            "modviento":"3" ,  
            "dirviento":"190" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 16:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        },
        { 
            "temp":"6.5" ,  
            "humrel":"0.57" ,  
            "precip":"0.0" ,  
            "modviento":"3.4" ,  
            "dirviento":"192" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 15:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        },
        { 
            "temp":"7.2" ,  
            "humrel":"0.47" ,  
            "precip":"0.0" ,  
            "modviento":"4.4" ,  
            "dirviento":"191" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 14:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        }
    ]}

Example using XML 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/wf/getalerts/?method=xml&module=wf&parameter=temp&fecha_ini=1421931600&fecha_fin=1422001600

REQUEST

ACCEPT:     
    application/xml

RESPONSE
Response code:     
    200 OK
Content-Type:        
    application/xml
Response body:    
    <contextML xmlns="http://ContextML/1.7" 
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"  
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://ContextML/1.7 ../ContextML-1.7.xsd">
        <ctxEls>
            <ctxEl>
                <contextProvider id="MyClient" v="1.2.1"></contextProvider>
                <entity id="123456789123" type="imei"></entity>
                <scope>cell</scope>

                <datapart>
                    <par n="temp">6.29</par>
                    <par n="humrel">0.60</par>
                    <par n="precip">0.20</par>
                    <par n="modviento">3</par>
                    <par n="dirviento">190</par>
                    <par n="timestamp">2015-01-22 16:00:00</par>
                    <par n="entity">imei</par>
                    <par n="scope">cell</par>
                    <par n="idsensor"></par>
                </datapart>
            </ctxEl>
            <ctxEl>
                <contextProvider id="MyClient" v="1.2.1"></contextProvider>
                <entity id="123456789123" type="imei"></entity>
                <scope>cell</scope>
                <timestamp>2015-01-21T22:10:18+01:00</timestamp>
                <expires>2020-01-31T22:10:08+01:00</expires>
                <datapart>
                    <par n="temp">6.5</par>
                    <par n="humrel">0.57</par>
                    <par n="precip">0.0</par>
                    <par n="modviento">3.4</par>
                    <par n="dirviento">192</par>
                    <par n="timestamp">2015-01-22 15:00:00</par>
                    <par n="entity">imei</par>
                    <par n="scope">cell</par>
                    <par n="idsensor"></par>
                </datapart>
            </ctxEl>
            <ctxEl>
                <contextProvider id="MyClient" v="1.2.1"></contextProvider>
                <entity id="123456789123" type="imei"></entity>
                <scope>cell</scope>
                <timestamp>2015-01-23T22:10:18+01:00</timestamp>
                <expires>2020-01-31T22:10:08+01:00</expires>
                <datapart>
                    <par n="temp">7.2</par>
                    <par n="humrel">0.47</par>
                    <par n="precip">0.0</par>
                    <par n="modviento">4.4</par>
                    <par n="dirviento">191</par>
                    <par n="timestamp">2015-01-22 14:00:00</par>
                    <par n="entity">imei</par>

    </contextML>

Overview:
What you get

Scene Manager DSE is a module which allows client applications (e.g. mobile apps for facility managers developed by third parties) to subscribe to customized alerts associated to the parameters of a building energy management/monitoring system. Alerts are triggered based on predefined ‘scenes’ which can be created by the client. These scenes are a combination of ranges of values for different parameters of the building system. If the conditions set in the scene are fulfilled, then an alert is triggered.

The reference implementation provided shows the application of the DSE for managing the subscription to customized alerts associated to the parameters of different systems and services integrated in the FINESCE Madrid trial, namely:
  • Weather forecast service
  • Wireless monitoring and metering network
  • Building energy generation and storage management system
  • Building Management System, remotely controlled through a proprietary platform called Building Control Centre.

DSE Version 1.0

Why to get it

A reference implementation of a module for managing subscriptions to customized alerts associated to building system parameters handled through the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker GE. The current implementation is based on Context Awareness Platform, but it can be modified to use it with Orion.

Target Usage

This DSE aims to help application developers who need to give end users an efficient access to data from building energy management/monitoring systems (or any other monitoring system in other domains). Customized alerts are an easy way of providing end users with information relevant for them.

Open Specifications
